metadata.notes: All Saints Day sermon delivered in 1997 at St. John’s, Essex, CT.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher uses CP to dismiss 'politically correct police' and 'multiculturalists' early on. He also uses a dogmatic CP voice to insist that 'every Christian should read Ecclesiastes... once a year.'
quotes: the politically correct police aren’t going to let us call it Halloween any more
we Christians have a job of work to do
Every Christian should read Ecclesiastes from beginning to end at least once a year.

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The care is supportive in acknowledging shared suffering, but it leans toward a 'Rescuer' position by emphasizing the congregation's inability to solve their own existential dread.
quotes: It is full of encouragement, hope, and comfort, especially for oppressed people.

adult.analysis: The preacher engages the Adult by presenting a 'quiz' and comparing canonical vs. apocryphal texts. He uses logic and literary analysis (Macbeth, Princeton professors) to process reality.
quotes: I have a little quiz for you this morning.
I’m going to read two short passages, and you figure out which one is in the Bible.
It all depends on where Revelation came from.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher speaks from a place of personal vulnerability (AC) regarding his family's tragedies, but he also pushes the congregation into a 'fearful' AC role by emphasizing the 'gloom' of death to make them compliant for the solution.
quotes: I suppose I was thinking about myself and how some day my own children would be saying the same thing
which I have deliberately drawn as gloomily as possible

free_child_FC.analysis: Authentic joy is largely deferred to the afterlife or the 'King of Glory.' The present life is described as 'struggle' and 'disappointment.'
quotes: I hope that gives you goose bumps.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher starts with an Adult-to-Adult intellectual inquiry (the quiz) but shifts to a Parent-to-Child dynamic by intensifying the listener's existential fear (Gimmick) before offering the Rescuer's solution.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: The social message is 'Let's study scripture together,' while the psychological message is 'You are helpless against death; only my interpretation of Revelation can save you from despair.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' lies in the deliberate amplification of gloom ('I have deliberately drawn as gloomily as possible') to force a specific emotional response.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch (Redemption)

formula_g_analysis.con: An intellectual quiz about the Bible.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's fear of being forgotten/death.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Moving from the 'honest' pessimism of Ecclesiastes to the 'resplendent' Revelation.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: Relief from the manufactured gloom, dependent on the preacher's authority.

evidence_quotes: I guess you can tell I have set you up.
from this perspective, which I have deliberately drawn as gloomily as possible, let us listen again...

detected_games.name: Ain't It Awful

formula_g_analysis.con: Discussing the 'politically correct' world and the decay of family.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: Nostalgia and shared frustration with modern culture.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The preacher becomes the one who 'knows the end of the book.'
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A sense of 'us vs. them' (Christians vs. Multiculturalists/Princeton professors).

evidence_quotes: the politically correct police aren’t going to let us call it Halloween any more
I look at those pictures now and I wonder who that family is.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. He offers the 'only power that can make it different' (God/The Word) to a congregation he has just rendered helpless.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Low. Manifests briefly against 'multiculturalists' and 'Ivy League professors.'
preacher_roles.victim: Medium. He identifies as a victim of time and aging ('our daughter has not yet had her brain tumor').

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim. They are addressed as people who are 'damaged, unfinished, and bent out of shape' and unable to answer ultimate questions.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Limited. The escape is through faith in the 'eternal word,' but the preacher maintains the role of the one who 'drew back the curtain.'

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is a masterclass in 'Bait and Switch' homiletics. It uses high-level Adult ego engagement (literary quotes, textual comparison) to mask a deeply Parent-Child psychological dynamic. By intentionally amplifying the 'gloom' of the human condition (Ecclesiastes), the preacher creates a psychological deficit in the listener that only his 'Rescuer' message (Revelation) can fill. While theologically orthodox, the method relies on emotional manipulation—breaking the listener down to build them back up.
strengths: Strong Adult ego engagement through intellectual rigor.
Authentic vulnerability regarding personal family tragedy.
High level of 'Here-and-Now' reality testing regarding death.
areas_for_improvement: Heavy reliance on 'Critical Parent' judgments of culture.
Intentional manipulation of the listener's emotional state ('deliberately drawn as gloomily as possible').
Creating dependency by framing the preacher as the one who 'knows the end of the book' for the 'helpless' listener.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Avoid 'setting up' the congregation with quizzes designed to fail. Instead of 'deliberately' making things gloomy to heighten the contrast, allow the Adult ego of the listener to grapple with the tension of the texts without forcing a manufactured emotional 'payoff'.
